addText.text: {b}Participant Information: Perceptual Ratings of Same- and Other-Race Faces{/b} Introduction People are normally very good at recognising familiar faces (i.e., faces of friends, colleagues or famous people) but relatively poor at recognising faces that are unfamiliar to them (Hancock, Bruce & Burton, 200). In particular, people are very poor at recognising faces of other races (‘the other-race effect’, ORE). A vast amount of research has been conducted to understand why ORE occurs. Evidence suggests that it is not due to racial prejudice but rather a combination of perceptual and social categorisation processes that provoke ORE. This experiment will examine peoples' perception of same and other-race faces. What will I be asked to do if I take part? You will be presented with 4 blocks of 23 faces. One block will display Caucasian faces one at a time and the other block will display Japanese faces one at a time. You will see each face for 15s and during that time you will be asked to rate the face on 5 factors on a 7-point scale: attractiveness, distinctiveness, memorability, familiarity and likeability. You will also be asked to complete a questionnaire assessing how much contact you have had with both Japanese and white British faces. The experiment should take no longer than 30 minutes to complete. Will my data be anonymous and confidential? The names of all participants will remain anonymous throughout the project. Data and responses gained will not be able to be linked to the name of the participant and data will be treated confidentially, only used for the purposes stated here and not shared with anyone beyond the research team. Do I have to take part? No, you do not have to take part. You can withdraw from the experiment without any detriment to you. In order to withdraw at a later date you will need to email the experimenter (using the email address below) and provide them with a password, which you will create on the next page. The password will be used to identify your data. Where can I obtain further information if I need it? Further information can be received from Natalie Butcher at N.Butcher@tees.ac.uk, Dr Kazuyo Nakabayashi at K.Nakabayashi@hull.ac.uk or Prof Toby Lloyd-Jones at t.j.lloyd-jones@swansea.ac.uk.

{b}Consent Page{/b}
---1. Have you read the Participant Information Sheet? ---2. Do you understand that you do not need to take part in the study and if you do you are free to withdraw:- * By 30th June 2015 * without having to give a reason for withdrawing * and without detriment to you? ---3. Have you received enough information about the study? ---4. Do you agree to take part in this study? ---Participant age: ---Participant gender:

addText.text: {b}Instructions page:{/b} You are going to see a series of faces for 15s. Please view each face for several seconds before rating it indicating how distinctive, likeable, attractive, memorable and familiar the face is. {b}Distinctiveness{/b} is how difficult you think it would be to pick that person out of a crowd {b}Likeability{/b} is about whether you think the person looks likeable {b}Attractiveness{/b} is whether you think the person is attractive looking. {b}Memorability{/b} is about whether you think it would be easy to remember that person {b}Familiarity{/b} is about whether the face is confusable with somebody you know. When rating the faces please make use of the whole scale as the scale is from 1 to 7. Do not use the same number (e.g., 3 or 5) all the time without thinking of other numbers on the scale.
Starting the next block of 23 trials (there are 4 blocks in total).

How difficult would it be to pick this person out of a crowd? 1 = ‘Not Difficult’ and 7 = ‘Very Difficult’---Does this person look as if he would be likable? ‘Not Likable’ and 7= ‘Very Likable’---Is this person attractive looking? 1 = ‘Not Attractive’ and 7= ‘Very attractive’---Would this face be easy to remember? 1= ‘Easy to Remember’ and 7 = ‘Difficult to Remember’---Is this face confusable with someone you know? 1 = ‘Not Confusable’ and 7 = ‘Very Confusable’

For the following questionnaire, we would like you to indicate how well the following statements represent the type of interactions you have with Oriental (e.g., Japanese, Chinese, or Koreans) and Caucasian people. Please indicate the extent to which each statement represents your interactions

addMultipleChoice.labels: 1 very strongly disagree,2 strongly disagree,3 disagree,4 agree,5 strongly agree,6 very strongly agree

addText.text: (1) I know lots of oriental people---(2) I interact with Caucasian people during recreational periods---(3) I live, or have lived in an area where I interact with Caucasian people---(4) I live, or have lived in an area where I interact with Oriental people---(5) I interact with Oriental people during recreational periods---(6) I interact with Caucasian people on a daily basis---(7) I socialize a lot with Caucasian people---(8) I went to a secondary school where I interacted with Oriental students---(9) I socialize a lot with Oriental people---(10) I know lots of Caucasian people---(11) I generally only interact with Oriental people---(12) I interact with Oriental people on a daily basis---(13) I went to a secondary school where I interacted with Caucasian students---(14) I generally only interact with Caucasian people---(15) I have lived in a country where the people are predominately Caucasian---(16) I have lived in a country where the people are predominately Oriental

{b}Participant Debrief{/b} The aim of the project is to assess the degree to which pre-experimental differences in stimulus representations, that is attractiveness, familiarity, likability, distinctiveness and memorability, exist within the ‘cross-race effect’, whereby people are poorer at processing faces of difference races to their own, in face recognition. It is important to assess such differences cross-culturally in order to establish whether such factors might explain already differences in face recognition across same- and other-race faces, and also to validate stimuli used in past and future research. We therefore asked Caucasian-British and Asian-Japanese participants to rate a series of same- and other-race faces on the five indices describe above, using an online experiment developed with Xperiment Mobi software (www.xperiment.mobi) which is designed for the administering of Psychological experiments. The face rating measures selected here have been used in previous studies using other racial groups. For instance, Meissner, Brigham and Butz (2005) looked at the influence of attractiveness, familiarity, likability, distinctiveness and memorability on the recognition of White and Black faces by White and Black college-aged males. Details of their study and findings are as follows: Memory for own- and other-race faces: a dual-process approach. Christian A. Meissner, John C. Brigham and David A. Butz (2005) Abstract: The current studies assessed the phenomenological basis of the cross-race effect by examining predictions of various social-cognitive mechanisms within a dual-process framework for both the perception (Experiment 1) and recognition (Experiment 2) of own- and other-race faces. Taken together, the current studies demonstrated that differential performance on own-race faces was largely due to qualitative differences in the encoding of facial information represented by a recollection process. Furthermore, false recollections with high ratings of confidence occurred more often when participants encoded and responded to unfamiliar other-race faces. The theoretical implications of these findings for the phenomenology of skilled perceptual-memory are discussed, and the applied consequences of the cross-race effect as an encoding-based phenomenon are considered. Thank you for taking part. {b}PlEASE GIVE THIS CODE TO YOUR EXPERIMENTER: GX723{/b}
